title: Just Primes II
text:
Given a positive integerN, calculate the minimum number of distinct primes required such that their sum equals toN. Also calculate the number of different ways to select these primes. Two ways are considered to be differentiffthere exists at least one prime in one set not existing in the other.InputThe first line contains an integerT, denoting the number of test cases. Each of the next subsequentTlines contain a positive integerN.Constraints1 ≤ T ≤ 500,0001 ≤ N ≤ 500,000OutputFor each test case, output two integersXandYseparated by a single space.Xdenotes the minimum number of distinct primes required such that their summation equals toN, andYis the number of ways to select these primes. If it is not possible to expressNas a summation of distinct primes, setXandYto-1and output them. You can safely assume that the answer will always fit in a signed 32 bit integer.Sample Input20
1
2
10
27
100
666
1000
1729
4572
4991
10000
100000
480480
482790
499799
499847
499901
499979
499999
500000Sample Output-1 -1
1 1
2 1
3 3
2 6
2 31
2 28
3 2393
2 110
3 13396
2 127
2 810
2 8499
2 8291
3 31121027
3 31139901
3 31124665
1 1
3 30974053
2 3052Warm UpToo hard? Try the easier version here -Just Primes
